awd_titl_txt: Recycling of Noble Gases in Ring-bearing Silicates
awd_abstract_narration:
Volatiles such as water (H2O) and carbon dioxide (CO2) are well-known to be key to the climate and atmosphere of the Earth, and the life that depends on them.  Less well known is that these volatiles are also abundant in the Earth's interior.  Indeed, there is probably as much water inside the Earth as on the surface.  Thus the transfer of volatiles in and out of the Earth exerts a fundamental control on both the climate and the large-scale movement of the Earth's interior.  However, it is difficult to geochemically trace the major volatiles (H2O, CO2, S, Cl and F) as they have few isotopes, which are key geochemical tracing tools.  The noble gases (He, Ne, Ar, Kr and Xe) are also volatile.  Though low in concentration, they are isotopically rich and so are ideal for tracing the movement of volatiles.  However, there is little data on how the noble gases behave at high pressures inside the Earth, greatly restricting their use as tracers.  Building on our previous high-pressure noble gas experiments, this study will measure the solubility of noble gases in a range of minerals.  This will allow better estimates of volatile fluxes into and out of the Earth, as well as better tracing of the geochemical evolution of the Earth's interior.

The fundamental issue that will be addressed by the project is how noble gases are incorporated into subducting lithosphere (slabs).  Subduction is the main mechanism for bringing volatiles into the mantle.  Most models have assumed that noble gases, having no charge, would not bind into minerals, and so slabs would not contain significant noble gas contents.  In a previous study, my group demonstrated that He, Ne and Ar are incorporated into amphibole and that they are bound into Si-O ring structures in the crystal lattice.  Such ring structures are present in a variety of minerals in subducting slabs.  The proposed research will use high-pressure experiments combined with laser-ablation noble gas mass-spectrometry to determine noble gas solubilities in ring-structured minerals (e.g. serpentine, chlorite and mica).  The data will be used to quantify both the amount of noble gases incorporated into slabs as well as how the noble gases are fractionated from each other.  The data will be used to construct models aimed at matching the observed noble gas concentration and isotopic ratios in the mantle, which will constrain rates of cycling of noble gases into the mantle.  As the noble gases should trace the movements of H2O and CO2, the noble gas flux model will constrain H2O and CO2 cycling as well.  This work fits well with a number of recent geochemical observations that indicate recycling of noble gases is more important than previously thought.  It will provide the first measurements of noble gas solubilities in a range of minerals and so will allow, for the first time, quantitative estimates of noble gas recycling rates.

por.por_cntn:
Broadly speaking, the goal of the project was to further our understanding of the global cycling of volatiles (including water, carbon dioxide and nitrogen) from the Earth’s surface into its interior and back again. This exchange between the interior and surface is a key component of our atmosphere and climate. In particular, this study focused on how the noble gases (helium, neon, argon, krypton and xenon) can be used to trace that volatile cycle. While their concentrations are low, and they do not play an active role in climate or properties of the Earth’s interior, their relative inertness and large number of isotopes, makes them excellent geochemical tracers. But, to use them as tracers, we need to know how they behave chemically, and very little work has been done in this area.

To address this lack of data, we experimentally studied how noble gases dissolve into minerals. In particular, we focused on minerals (serpentine and amphibole) that are important in the return of volatiles to the Earth’s interior at subduction zones. Previous work by our group discovered that noble gases preferentially dissolve into minerals that have rings of Si-O4 tetrahedra in the crystalline structure. Many minerals in subducting crust and lithosphere have such rings, implying that substantial amounts of noble gases may be subducted into the Earth’s interior, contrary to many previous models.

Our previous work had focused primarily on He, with some Ne and Ar data. However, most evidence for recycling of noble gases is recorded in isotopes of Kr and Xe. So in this study, we measured the partitioning of all noble gases. Our data reveal that the main minerals carrying noble gases into the mantle do indeed have high noble gas solubilities, even for heavy noble gases, and different minerals have distinct noble gas fractionation patterns. Amazingly, these fractionation patterns match different types of volcanism quite well. Volcanism is a primary path by which volatiles are returned to the Earth’s surface from the interior. That the noble gas patterns in subducting minerals are seen in volcanos suggests a robust volatile recycling system that implants volatiles into even the deepest regions of the mantle.

Most of the Earth’s magmatism occurs at mid-ocean ridges. The systematics of Ar-Kr-Xe of mid-ocean ridge basalts (MORB) are very similar to the particular fractionation patterns we measure in serpentine. This suggests that most volatiles in the mantle are derived from deeper parts of subducting slabs. We are currently using this, along with known volatile contents of subducting serpentinite, to calculate a global cycling budget for H2O, CO2 and N. Some ocean island basalts, like Hawaii, also seem to have a large component of volatiles from serpentine. Because some isotopes of Xe are short-lived, we not only can trace how much volatiles have been subducted, but also when they were subducted. Recent studies of xenon isotopes (Parai, Nature 2018l) show that much of the Xe must have been recycled later in Earth history, after ~2.5 billion years ago. If so, our work suggests that may have been a time when subduction of large amounts of serpentine first began to be subducted via plate tectonics.

Amphibole appears to fractionate Ar-Kr-Xe even more than serpentine. A number of ocean island basalts, particularly in Polynesia, have very similar noble gas fractionation to amphibole, suggesting their volatiles were primarily recycled via altered oceanic crust. This is consistent with previous studies that showed their Pb isotopes were also consistent with recycling of oceanic crust. It also implies that amphibole is not the main source of volatiles in the bulk of the mantle, and so either must largely devolatilize at shallow depths in subduction zones, or bypass the main volume of mantle and sink to the core-mantle boundary, after being converted to denser eclogite.

The broad impact of the study is that by providing the first high quality partitioning data of noble gases in subducting minerals, we are building a tool set to improve our understanding of the global volatile cycle. This includes being able to trace particular components of subducting lithosphere through subduction zones, into the deep mantle and back. Our improved models of volatile cycling should benefit researchers studying both the Earth’s interior and its atmosphere. Via the study, a graduate student (Jack Krantz), was trained in a range of cutting-edge experimental and analytical methods. Also, because Kr and Xe are quite expensive, we constructed a specialized experimental device that minimizes the amount of gas used. To our knowledge there is only one other device like it (at RPI, Bruce Watson lab). This device will be useful for our future work, and also for other researchers interested with working with heavy noble gases, including synthesis of analytical standards.
